title: 105_hr3497
content: The "Individual Investment Account Act of 1998" establishes individual investment accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Individual Investment Account Act of 1998 allows individuals to deduct cash payments made to an individual investment account established for their benefit. An individual investment account is a trust created in the U.S. for the exclusive benefit of an individual, meeting specific requirements. The trust for an individual investment account must meet specific requirements, including accepting only cash contributions, being administered by a bank or qualified person, not investing in collectibles, and ensuring trust assets are not invested in prohibited assets. The trust assets must not be commingled with other property except in a common trust fund or common investment fund. Contributions are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year. Distributions are subject to specific tax treatment unless otherwise provided. Any distribution from an individual investment account is taxable unless it is a qualified 1st-time homebuyer distribution, which is a payment received by a first-time homebuyer from the account for purchasing a home. Qualified 1st-time homebuyer distributions allow individuals to use payments from their investment accounts for qualified acquisition costs on a principal residence within 120 days. The total amount for such distributions cannot exceed $20,000, and the basis of the residence will be reduced accordingly. The transfer of an individual's interest in an individual investment account to a former spouse under a divorce decree is not taxable and will be treated as the spouse's account. The individual investment account transferred to a former spouse under a divorce decree is exempt from taxation unless it no longer qualifies as such. It may be subject to taxes on unrelated business income. Loss of exemption for individual investment account if individual engages in prohibited transaction under section 4975, causing the account to cease as of the first day of the taxable year. "If an individual engages in a prohibited transaction under section 4975, causing an individual investment account to cease on the first day of the taxable year, all assets in the account are treated as distributed at fair market value on that day." "When an individual investment account is used as security for a loan, the portion used is treated as distributed to that individual. Rollover contributions do not apply if the amount is paid into another investment account within 60 days. Cost-of-Living Adjustment is also considered." "In the case of any taxable year after 1998, the $20,000 amount in subsection (c)(2)(B) is increased by a cost-of-living adjustment based on the calendar year. Rounding rules apply to the increased dollar amount." The text discusses rounding rules for dollar amounts in a specific section and defines custodial accounts as trusts if certain conditions are met. The trustee of an individual investment account must report to the Secretary and the account holder on contributions, distributions, and other relevant matters as required by regulations. Reports must be filed and furnished in a timely manner. Additionally, deductions for individual investment account contributions are allowed in arriving at adjusted gross income, and these accounts are exempt from estate tax. Section 2046 of the tax code is redesignated as section 2047, with a new section inserted after 2045. "Section 2046 is now section 2047, with a new section added after 2045 for individual investment accounts." Individual investment accounts are excluded from the gross estate value and are not subject to Section 1014.
